Award.AwardTitle: Harmonic Analysis and Partial Differential Equations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this project is to advance the principal investigator's research in the development of various aspects of harmonic analysis and partial differential equations. The main foci of the project will be the study of "critical elements" in critical nonlinear and wave equations, the study of universal profiles for blow-up solutions, the study of defocusing energy supercritical wave equations, the development of the connection between issues of uniqueness of solutions to parabolic and dispersive equations with Hardy's uncertainty principle for the Fourier transform, the study of local and global inverse problems, and the development of the theory of homogenization for elliptic equations and systems on Lipschitz domains.

Many of the topics under study in this project have their origins in problems coming from physics, engineering, and biotechnology. It is hoped that the proposed research will have a synergistic effect between those fields and the mathematical fields of analysis and geometry. One prominent feature of the proposal is the principal investigator's collaborative research with female mathematicians. The broader impacts of the project reside in the wide dissemination of the results obtained, through publication of articles and monographs and through lectures, courses, and web-sites, in the training of students and postdocs, in the increased participation of underrepresented groups, and in the many connections with other fields of science and technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of this project is the development of new ideas and methods to understand a variety of problems in partial differential equations and harmonic analysis. Some of the areas of research studied were nonlinear wave and dispersive equations, periodic homogenization and anisotropic inverse problems. These areas originate in fields such as nonlinear wave propagation, heterogeneous materials and medical imaging. In the area of nonlinear wave and dispersive equations, the PI and collaborators developed powerful new ideas and methods that have already had a broad impact in the field. With these new methods, the PI and collaborators have been able to solve long-standing problems on singularity formation and long-time asymptotics. In the area of periodic homogenization, the PI and collaborators have been able to obtain precise asymptotic rates of convergence of the highly oscillating problems to their homogeneous limits, a great "simplification" of complex phenomena. In the area of inverse problems, the PI and collaborators have been able to treat, for the first time, reconstruction poblems for a collection of anisotropic settings, which reflect realistic scenarios.

The broad impact of this project is both scientific and educational. On the scientific side, the results and methods developed in this project will have  impact in related fields such as optics, lasers, mathematical physics, material science, medical imaging and geophysical prospection. On the educational side, the PI has developed graduate courses based on this research. In additon, the PI has lectured extensively and has taught a number of summer courses based on this research. The results of the PI's research on this project have been widely disseminated through publication in leading specialized journals, the posting of preprints in electronic preprint servers and the PI's webpage. In addition, the PI has written a large number of survey papers giving expository accounts of his results on this project and has just published a research monograph on his research on nonlinear wave equations. The PI has been very actively involved in the training of young researchers on topics related to the project. During the duration of this project, the PI has supervised 12 graduate students, with 7 of them completing their PhD during this project, and the remaining 5 being at various stages of their dissertation research. The PI has also supervised and collaborated extensively with postdoctoral researchers, having supervised 8 of them during this project.
